name: almajo
text: Your posts are usually commendably witty, but is it weird that they read as at least 20% more awesome because of your avatar?

name: spinynorman
text: That one wasn't all that witty, so I have no issue with my avatar imbuing it with a certain level of comedic verve.

name: pogo
text: And just who is your icon, anyway?

name: thorfinn
text: He is none other than Stephen Fry, I believe in one of the opening street conversation bits from an episode of "A Bit of Fry and Laurie, judging by the background.

name: pogo
text: Ah yes, a trip to Wikiland reveals quite a bit about Fry.  I did see about five minutes of Jeeves and Wooster, hated it.  Don't remember him from Black Adder.  Hope to catch some of his other work one day, Allah willing.  (Death to Amerika)

name: gambolholic
text: That's a bit quick to judge don't you say?  I guess in the few minutes that you watched it there wasn't a constant stream of sub-par jokes like in sitcoms or stupid frat-boy comedies.  Sorry if you had a totally legit reason for hating the show but I think it's sad that people hate shows/movies with great story lines and a hilarious script because it's a little slower paced or subtler (and for the record, I do enjoy sitcoms and stupid comedies from time to time).  Plus, it's one of Stephen Fry's funniest roles.

name: laserblade
text: Well, it's not a perfect show.  There are perfectly legitimate reasons to hate it.  The humor's a little smarmy, for instance.  And you do have to get into the storyline.  Five minutes from the middle of an episode, taken in isolation, wouldn't be that funny.  Not to say I don't like the show, but maybe you're going a little overboard by personally attacking someone who doesn't?

name: pogo
text: That's okay, I didn't take it personally.

name: pogo
text: Well I exaggerated a little.  I watched a show or two, really giving it a chance, because I usually like strange Brit humor.  But the characters were just too smarmy and overdone for my taste at that point in time.  Say, didn't one of the actors become House?

name: gambolholic
text: Yes he did.  Hugh Laurie played Wooster and later played House.  And sorry, I didn't mean to personally attack pogo,  I was just defending the show!

name: laserblade
text: Well I'm glad there's no hard feelings and stuff.

name: i_love_kate
text: Big hug, everyone!

name: lechatbotte
text: Swarmy was just the ticket to do the literary characters they were playing justice. I've yet to see Laurie take on a role that I didn't like, and Fry, well it's more like love! (His blackadder bit is better than Jeeves, but couldn't we all use a Jeeves to sort things out for us?)

name: voloshg
text: If you haven't seen Stephen Fry on Blackadder, you haven't seen Blackadder.

name: odei
text: I print a years worth of strips onto parchment and bind them in a leather and oak cover. I then let this book rest in the attic for 2 years to imbue it with that special must. After it has aged I take my white cotton gloves and tiny reading glasses and pour over the volume on a hot summer afternoon. I recommend that it be served with neat spiced rum or bourbon.

name: catgrl131
text: Man, you don't know the penis game? It's pretty awesome. First of all, you have to be in a public place. Person #1 says "penis" as quietly as they can, then person #2 says it a little louder, taking turns (with as many people as there are that want to play), getting louder and louder, and whenever a person gets too ashamed to continue, they lose. Last person standing wins. I myself have witnessed a game in which each person was extremely proud and stubborn, so I bore witness to about 45 minutes of two ladies screaming PENIS!!!!!!! at the top of their lungs until person #2 lost her voice. It was pretty frikkin' sweet.

name: pogo
text: Hmm, since I'm a guy, it might be more fun to shout VAGINA.  But making a public spectacle is really not my cup of tea, thanks.

name: geysershitdick
text: I like to imagine that the guy who thinks you should wear a tuxedo while shooting fish, the fellow who has trouble losing weight, the dude who lost a brother in a book judging-related incident, and the man with the particularly fecund wife are all, in fact, the same person.

name: greyfield
text: The question is, who on earth goes to a comedy club at two in the afternoon?

name: kvanever
text: Anybody want to explain the one in panel five to me?

name: littlefatdog
text: If the building you're in is on fire, you should hurry up and judge the book whatever way you can and get out! Many brothers have been lost due to indecisiveness over methodology of book judging.

name: silver_lake
text: I completely concur. Chubb'd.

name: mashuren
text:
If the building's on fire, you should probably just judge the book by its cover instead of taking the time to leaf through it first.

I lost a brother that way. "Just one more paragraph!" he shouted at me, through the smoke, but by then it was too late.

name: jamers
text:
In his defense, he was reading The Brother's Karamazov , and he hadn't quite pinned down Alyosha's character.

Damn you, Dostoevksy, for your engaging characters and compelling story lines!!!

name: professorhazard
text:
It's a special kind of self-loathing that results from realizing you did everything right - spelled all the names correctly, underlined the book's title, and even made a pretty nice joke - and then you see that you put an apostrophe in the word "Brothers".

But it's cool, it's cool. At the end of the day, The Brother Is, in fact, Karamazov.

name: jamers
text:
I would like to take a moment and quote Charlie Brown here....

AUUUUUUUUGGHHHHH!!!

name: johnnyc
text: A friend of mine actually created a character map of all of the characters in The Brothers Karamazov . He was having trouble keeping track of all the nicknames, names and relationships. I don't blame him at all.

name: professorhazard
text: Would you say it was hard to... juggle all the information?

name: tekende
text: I don't see what you did there.

name: jamers
text: The Flying Karamazov Brothers

name: odei
text:
"international fame in the world of juggling"

I do not understand some hobbies.

name: spinynorman
text: To be fair, the fire joke really confused me. Then again it was really early in the morning and it was pretty tough following five-year old logic, if it may be called "logic."

name: professorhazard
text: I thought the joke was saying that if you see a building on fire, you should assume it is on fire, as opposed to wondering if it really is on fire just because it appears to be. However, the above comments have convinced me that this was not the joke's intent.

name: spinynorman
text: That's what I thought, too. Glad to hear I wasn't the only one.

name: biff
text: I thought that at first too.  After hearing the other interpretation I am still not convinced it wrong.  And I think it is funnier that way anyway.

name: biff
text:
There is an "is" missing from the above post.

Here is is:

[t]is[/s]

name: tekende
text: Yeah, I tried to make the same joke (more or less) the other day and got lamed for it too. I think people thought I was being pissy. Oh well...not our fault if other people don't pay attention.

name: biff
text:
Apparently some people have difficulty discerning what my avatar depicts. At least, as I have been told.

I appreciate humor based on me having my head up my ass. After all, I chose it as my avatar on purpose.

I apologize to anyone who gets lamed just because I have my head up my ass.

name: professorhazard
text: A surprisingly clear-viewed statement, courtesy of the man with his head up his ass.

name: irondave

name: jamers
text:
At first glance, I thought it was some sort of bull with white horns.

At second glance, I realized you had your head in regions better left unexplored.

name: girdag
text:
Great, now I'm imagining Phillipe with Jimmy Carr's voice. And I hate that smug git.

Also, could anyone explain the joke in the fourth panel for me? Am I just being slow?

name: irondave
text: I think the idea is that if you call it something other than "dessert" it's not as fattening.

name: chuvak
text: I thought it was that pudding just sounds unappetizing, and therefore you wouldn't want to eat it. Having had the dessert the British call "pudding" I can for sure state that it is so fattening it makes you fat if you breathe next to it.

name: abreez_e
text:
Joke post-mortem: A verb was deliberately omitted.

Instead of eating dessert, English people say pudding.

Saying pudding involves less ingestion of sugary post-main substances and you are on the road to being svelte and lissom, just like an English person.

name: girdag
text: A chubby for you, sir, that then makes sense. I bow to your greater intellect.

name: hellofyellin
text: Chubbed for usage of lissom.

name: brokeaccount
text: A comment left by brokeaccount was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by missbee, gothfae, InspectorGadget)

name: irondave
text:
Quote:
Damn weird United Statsians. Half of you won't touch anything that still looks like it came from an animal, and the other half won't eat something if they didn't haul it out of the woods themselves and gut it with their teeth.

Here you have nicely summarized our "Red State - Blue State" divide. We are indeed about 50-50 on these points, hence our very close national elections.

name: whoisspain
text: However, in neither area does chicken taste like it used to.

name: straw
text: Or should.

name: hellofyellin
text: This truly makes me sad.  It's a bit creepy that I have never really tasted a chicken-y chicken, a true pastured chicken.  Once I get settled, I'm going to look for one, and cook it up real good, to see what I've been missing.

name: chuvak
text: I'm with you on the heart eating. That's OK. But Yorkshire pudding DOES NOT taste like pancakes. I don't care if it's made out of fucking care bears and win, it tastes like pure hell.

name: cpnglxynchos
text:
i laughed very loudly when i read the last sentence of your comment while i was at the library. people stopped reading books and children stopped crying to look at me.

care bears and win
too great.

name: professorhazard
text: Greater than the idea of pushing Care Bears into a meat grinder, whose crank plays a music-box melody when turned?

name: cpnglxynchos
text:
oh. my. dogg.

that is terrible...and also great..but i still think things tasting of care bears and win is greater.

name: professorhazard
text: ohh long john

name: cpnglxynchos
text: why i eyes ya

name: pyromancer
text: Can you describe a Spotted Dick?

name: whoisspain
text: I don't think us Brits can get too uppity about American squeamishness, seeing as the Europeans look down on us for getting all Scarlett O'Hara over a perfectly ordinary horse burger.

name: brokeaccount
text: I really like horse meat actually... I only found that out because I was on a day trip in France with my family when I was a kid, and at the end of the day we'd done the usual hypermarché thing and while we were in the car park my dad walked up to a burger van and got us all some burgers. We ate them, talking about how delicious they were, and then drove off towards the dock to catch the ferry home. Only when we drove around the other side of the van did we see that on the back it had a massive painting of two horses galloping through a field with the words LA VIANDE CHEVAL.

name: sncether
text: Which is of course the French for "You can run, but you can't hide".

name: woodenteeth
text: oh yeeeeeeaahhhhh. virtual chubby for you.

name: professorhazard
text: I thought it was French for "Quarter Pounder with Cheese".

name: thorfinn
text: A comment left by thorfinn was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by straw, wigglestick, I_Love_Kate)

name: hellofyellin
text: I find it strange that many of you Brits don't consider yourselves European.  Is this a strictly a matter of geography? Please explain, I'd like to understand.

name: lawbot
text:
As a matter of strict geography, we are part of Europe, but not of continental Europe. As a matter of fact, we are European.

The basis of this attitude is that many britons are intensely xenophobic, and so make as much as possible of what are relatively small differences. In fact, British traditions are identifiably distinct from the main body of European culture, but that's all it is - a branch.

name: missbee
text: Didn't mean to lame you, dude. You made good points.

name: cmr
text: A comment left by cmr was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by divot, lawbot, Flyffe, I_Love_Kate, Satyr, Dasuta)

name: brokeaccount
text:
No... But we are Britons.

I'm willing to concede to US Americans. Or Yankees. Or Usonians. America's a pretty big continent.

name: thorfinn
text: A comment left by thorfinn was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by straw, lawbot, Flyffe, Satyr)

name: professorhazard
text: I prefer to just help usher in the world of the 31st century by calling myself and others Earthicans.

name: flazisismuss
text: I am not acknowledging the suzerainty of the United States, at least while Bush is in the White House, so I describe myself only as a Californian.  Until I can find a way to move out of this shithole of a state - then I'll have to think of something else.

name: brokeaccount
text: Don't get sore just 'cause you know I'm right. Take it like a man!

name: brokeaccount
text:
Or to put it a less childish way:

People from the continent of Africa are called Africans. People from the country South Africa which is on the continent of Africa are called South Africans in order to differentiate the people from the country with the word "Africa" in it from the people who live on the contient called Africa. Therefore the same ought to apply to America and the United States of America.

name: irondave
text:
I took no offense, and here is why: Twenty-plus years ago a very popular news anchor in St. Louis would from time to time make the very same point. You will notice that the usage has never really caught on. Your view is reasonable, yet quixotic.

Politicization follows:

I also can't help but note that many of the people in the US who pay lip service to this idea are the ones grousing the loudest about the most obvious agent for bringing this usage about: NAFTA and its expansion to our other American neighbors.

name: wittyname
text:
And then chaos fell on Assetbar.

/plays ominous music

name: brokeaccount
text:
For a moment I got NAFTA confused with NAMBLA.

Both are pretty bad, though.

name: irondave
text: Perfect.

name: lawbot
text: I do no like you, and I do not respect you. Also, I do not think your parents raised you well.

name: dagdaollathir
text: I think you're getting English cooking confused with Scottish...

name: hbaranov
text: Your anger toward British cuisine, whilst common, is unjustified.

name: heccibiggs
text:
Fuckoff Yorkshire pudding is amazing!! I didn't read any of your comment after than, I will continue to do so now.

Okay no one I know has eaten bread and dripping since like the late 50s. I'm guessing you visited the North.

name: lawbot
text: No, no you haven't eaten "the dessert the British call pudding," because there is no one such dessert. It is a name of a course in the meal. It would be like me saying I had eaten the dish americans call "entree" (erroneously).

name: chuvak
text: I'm always confused by the variety of things people in the UK and Ireland will call pudding. I like black pudding and white pudding, which I ate in Ireland and am assuming is made out of meat or blood or something that I don't want to know what it is... but Yorkshire pudding was not OK with me. Not at all.

name: lawbot
text: That is because you are not OK with yourself.

name: chuvak
text: Perhaps I've only had bad batches. I will try it again and be penitent for my rash remarks. But if it sucks the next time, you and me have business.

name: whoisspain
text: Did you have it with roast beef and gravy? Really it is one of those foodstuffs that need to be eaten with something rather than eaten by itself.

name: morelaak
text:
more like the dish we call "fast food".

oh wait...

name: wigglestick
text:
English protestations over American standard usages that have been established for decades, sometimes for a couple centuries now, are a bit silly. In this case, "entree" used to refer exclusively to the "entry" (first) course of the main courses. Now, Americans use the word "entree" to mean the main course since there is only one main course. No one in America eats a full course dinner anymore, and I'm betting that very few people in the U.K. do either, unless it's at a formal state dinner. In any case, these usages are becoming deprecated.

21st century, my friend. Don't let language evolve out from under you.

name: lawbot
text: I don't. It's why I use English, not America's strangely old-fashioned tongue peppered with neo-logisms and strangely evolved, and typically pretentious, usages.

name: smilebuddha
text: I'm late to this party, but: look who's being a dick about terms.

name: irondave
text: This has the feeling of a clearance sale on jokes that can't otherwise be worked into the strip or a blog.

name: chuvak
text: EVERYTHING MUST GO!!!! JOKE WAREHOUSE ON ROUTE 17 - GET YOUR JOKES FROM THE SUPPLIER!!!

name: tekende
text: ROUTE TWO IN WEEKAPAUG!!!

name: dr_strangeglove
text: AFRICAN AMERICAN!? HAIL A CAB!

name: tekende
text: CONFUSE YOUR NEIGHBORS!

name: puguglypress
text: All humorous video clip of a really dorky black guy unable to hail a cab and getting splashed with water

name: josher
text: I get that feeling also, but they are good jokes so I don't mind.

name: slanger
text:
It has the same feeling as the "jokes" that were in one of the subscriber-only comics. An example: "A man with a parrot on his shoulder takes a seat at a bar. The fellow sitting next to him turns and says 'so, can I touch his dick?'" Chris' comment on it is that it's his best attempt to write actual "joke" jokes, and that he has no idea how to do so.
Did I just write an ad for Achewood, Subscriber Only? YES I DID!

name: lawbot
text: YES

name: chuvak
text: I am highly amused by the man in the audience that lost a brother who tried to hard to judge a book in a burning building. It is heroic  that someone took the time to judge literature by its full battery of characteristics despite the conflagration in aforementioned building. Applause to that man, a true American patriot.

name: spectre
text: See, when the building is burning, you have to decide which books to save: the works of Nabokov, the workout guides or WORKING by Studs Terkel. As debris begins to fall from the ceiling, one looks for a way to speed up the decision-making.

name: whoisspain
text: I saved How to Weep the Weepy Weep Way: The Novelisation

name: wigglestick
text: I have to know what that is.

name: tekende
text: I'll hit you with a rock!

name: blastradius
text: I did not picture an American going to those lengths to judge a book ... not unless it was a comic book.

name: loneal
text: Oh dang, my boss's name is Lazslo. This explains so much.

name: farqussus
text: The 2pm crowd at Laszlo's is particularly sophisticated.

name: falseprophet
text: They came for the 1 pm Junot Diaz book signing but then Philippe is five.

name: syx
text: Chubby for correct spelling.

name: falseprophet
text: Of "Philippe" or of "Junot Diaz"? Because technically, there should be some apostrophes over some vowels up in there but assetbar is intolerant of that kind of Mexican magical realism.

name: spectre
text: Come for the pierogi . . . stay for the comedy!

name: skoora
text:
Phillipe stars in...
The Otter Kings of Comedy!

name: nikopol
text:
Phillipe channeled Billy Idol before, maybe now he's channeling Steven Wright.

"Curiosity killed the cat, but for a while I was a suspect."

name: gregchant
text: Lost a brother that way

name: lawbot
text: Loopkin?

name: chuvak
text: I woke up this morning and everything in my apartment had been stolen and replaced with an exact duplicate.

name: nikopol
text: I stayed up all night playing poker with tarot cards. I got a full house and four people died.

name: johnnyc
text: I was born by Caesarean section, but you really can't tell... except that when I leave my house, I always go out the window.

name: sn0wman
text:
When I was a little kid we had a sand box. It was a quicksand box. I was an only child...

Eventually.

name: heccibiggs
text:
Damn, the audience are really feeling him. Is it easy to tell your innermost secrets to a five-year-old stuffed otter?

Also; notice how they're clapping, not laughing. Are these even jokes?

name: bjorntd
text: It's part joke, part performance art, part revelation.

name: falseprophet
text: Clap clap clap I find your ideas intriguing and would like to subscribe to your newsletter clap clap

name: synnah
text:
Alt-Text: "If homeless people are so clever, how come they canâ%uFFFD%uFFFDt fly?"

Assetbar backfires on Onstad!

name: bjorntd
text: You beat me to this by four minutes you terrible man.

name: synnah
text: I apologise. Here you go: £%u20ACöä'

name: synnah
text: WHERE ARE MY DIAMONDS, ASSETBAR?!

name: bjorntd
text: WHERE IS THE MONEY, LEBOWSKI?

name: professorhazard
text: Bring us ze money or ve kill ze girl, Le-boh-ski~.

name: opprobrium
text: yah, and ve cut off your chonson.

name: professorhazard
text: ... excuse me?

name: jamers
text: I think I might be okay with that.

name: opprobrium
text: VE CUT OFF YOUR CHONSON!

name: spinynorman
text: Trying to phonetically spell fake German accents from a Coen Bros movie is sure to end in shame and confusion every time.

name: professorhazard
text: Give the dude some credit. I had to set him up for the all-caps line so it would perfectly complement his avatar.

name: doublechocolate
text: at least he didn't suggest getting a tattoo of it

name: opprobrium
text: suck it, norman.

name: opprobrium
text: dammit, i'm sorry.  it's been a crappy day, sorry i snapped.

name: heccibiggs
text: Outstanding avatar/comment synergy.

name: hellofyellin
text: Yah und mebbe ve shtep on it and ve sqvuish it.

name: cpnglxynchos
text: as a wery old, i can fathom the scene to be with me.

name: hellofyellin
text: Looking always as I ever did.

name: hellofyellin
text:
Zehre ver zwei peanuts valkeenk dahn ze strausse, und von vas assaultetd.


...


Peanut

name: cpnglxynchos
text:
*chortles*

[cues up Deutschland Uber Alles]

name: dtuba
text: They're gonna kill THAT POOOORR WOMANNN

name: synnah
text: Oh, they're there now.

name: bjorntd
text: This only partially consoles.

name: awko
text: That Assetbar is no longer content with ruining our witty comments and is now beginning to go after greater targets.

name: riazm
text:
I love this alt text, I read it on the actual site where it says:

If homeless people are so clever, how come they can't fly?

name: bjorntd
text: It would appear that Assetbar is no friend of Mr. Onstad's alt text today. I get hell of angry diamonds peeping at me.

name: slanger
text: That is one hell of a mental picture!  A !

name: thorfinn
text: And another falls victim to assetbar's anti-plus sign ways.

name: dirtfarm
text: [url]http://www.bendependent.com/dirtfarm[IMGS OFF][/url]

name: bjorntd
text: To be fair, it's too galdanged early for BBCode.

name: opprobrium
text:
that picture is pregnant with laughs.

i know who's winning this game...

name: clever-nickname
text:
Certainly not I, because the last panel made me lose the game.

Sorry, guys. I lost the game.

name: thorfinn
text: And this in turn caused me to lose the game

name: achilleselbow
text: At first I thought the homeless guy was trying to force pizza into the old man's mouth.

name: chuvak
text: I see a man flying with a hammer and a heart tattoo on his ass pooping on a car. Daddy like.

name: professorhazard
text: That's a squeegee. Take time to learn to recognize the staples of homeless-based humor.

name: biff
text: And that is the point. He is shitting on the window so you need to have him wash it and then pay him a dollar.

name: professorhazard
text: Because even in a world where the homeless have super powers, they would still be preoccupied with making very small sums of money. Put a tuxedo on a bum and give him a hundred dollars, and tomorrow a man wearing a tuxedo with a hundred dollars' worth of booze in his veins is going to be wiping your windshield for quarters.

name: spectre
text: And if you ever need a plasma transfusion . . . you might just see some of that $100 of booze come back to you!

name: falseprophet
text:
I first read the joke in panel two as something a mafioso would say to intimidate a deli owner who has defaulted on his loan.

But that is silly. Philippe ended the mafia.

...Unless, in doing so, his soul became tainted by the spilled blood of the innocent.

name: farqussus
text: I think Onstad might be drawing parallels between we of the assetbar and they of the Laszlo crowd.

name: bjorntd
text: I think you're projecting.

name: odei
text: How rude!

name: tbtabby
text: If Comedy Central can give TV shows to Carlos Mencia, Sarah Silverman, and Larry the Cable Guy, they'd BETTER make an offer to Philippe soon.

name: norrin
text: Hey now, Sarah Silverman is funny. Her show is by no means great, but she is a funy lady.

name: bourbonsamurai
text: Yes, one of those things is not like the others.

name: professorhazard
text: In the interests of honesty, I'd be remiss in not stating that I find Larry the Cable Guy to be a pretty funny guy. Not that his content is particularly amusing. I just like listening to his accent slip (Daniel Lawrence Whitney - born in Nebraska, raised in Florida).

name: autrepoupee
text: Her show can be pretty funny sometimes, and she's giving some work to underutilized comedians like Jay Johnston and Brian Posehn.  Also, it's just nice to see a woman making jokes that aren't just about her period, her gay male friends, and her parents.  Margaret Cho, for example.  Or Kathy Griffin.  I do not like either of those people much at all.

name: loneal
text: Margaret Cho is a national hero, sir.

name: autrepoupee
text: I'm a lady, a lady who hates Margaret Cho. Cho, cho much.  I did like your comic though! I just read through it and it was very sweet.  I hope that is not creepy.

name: loneal
text: Oh shit! That is nice of you. I gotta get rid of all that shit in my profile, I put it there whenever I created my Assetbar account and then promptly forgot about it.

name: autrepoupee
text: Aw, it was good though!  Don't worry, I think I'm the only person who actually reads through people's Assetbar profiles.  I have a lot of free time, clearly.

name: wittyname
text: Now I'm intrigued! Link?

name: loneal
text: Nope, that shit is deleted. One of many creative writing projects that I reject as soon as it is born. I think it is a common thing among Creative Writing students. It is why we never have children.

name: bjorntd
text: Well, as a fellow creative writing aspirant, I thought it was plenty good. I just sympathized with the mortified feeling that you get when someone approaches you with your work. It's like "oh god I'm gonna get asked questions I'm gonna get asked questions I'm gonna have to LIE." But really they say something innocuous like "Great job on this" or "I enjoyed it" and you're left sort of disappointed that you couldn't talk about your own creation on a deep level. Even if you had to lie.

name: wigglestick
text: You work fast.

name: tekende
text: I hate Margaret Cho as well. Her entire act, as it were, can basically be summed up by scrunching up your face and screaming "GAY MEN!" over and over.

name: professorhazard
text: Don't give Comedy Central too much credit re: making business decisions. They green-light things that someone who enjoys the reflective surface of a spoon would consider a comedically risky proposition. Little Bush was renewed for a second season.

name: spinynorman
text: Those are the worst commercials I have ever seen in my life. I would rather watch apes being sexually abused and then spontaneously exploding than watch another Little Bush commercial.

name: spinynorman
text: Oh yeah, I do need to specify that I like apes just fine and would not like to see either of the above mentioned things.

name: professorhazard
text: I, too, would prefer to watch a Terry Gilliam cartoon.

name: spectre
text: Wasn't it CC that had THAT'S MY BUSH with Timothy Bottoms as the leader of less-free-every-day world? That was fun, at least for a while.

name: tekende
text: It had its moments.

name: bjorntd
text:
Watching a [i]Little Bush[/b] cartoon is not unlike the unpleasant feeling that you feel when you hear Real Bush's sound clips. You keep hoping to wake up in a cold sweat. Eventually you sympathize with the show for trying so hard, as if you were suffering from Stockholm syndrome.


HELLA POLITICIZED, YO.

name: divot
text: Dude, there's a new series of Rape An Ape?

name: lenoxus
text: Nah, just some cameos in the spinoff Abuse Kangaroos.

name: nymphadoria
text: First wives tend to be cockroaches.

name: farqussus
text: No way! Cockroaches are harder to kill.

name: spinynorman
text:
Have you tried a hammer?

With either?

name: farqussus
text: Yes. They are both quite agile.

name: odei
text: My auntie's ex-husband and current husband both have scars.

name: solobuttons
text: I like that one audience member tells Philippe to "tell it like it is" regarding barrels/tuxedos. Philippe is so doing that. That's really how things are.

name: woodenteeth
text: Phillipe needs his own sitcom. Reeeal bad.

name: chuvak
text: This strip poses a difficulty for me. I have a sorta voice in my head for all of the Achewood characters; Ray is deep and scratchy and kinda black sounding, beef is slightly more nasal but still reasonably deep voiced and speaks quietly, etc. But I have no idea what I think Phillipe sounds like. Anyone got any suggestions?

name: professorhazard
text: He sounds five.

name: chuvak
text: Thanks, noted.

name: anitrophaeron
text: I hear Slippy's voice from Starfox 64 when I read Philippe's lines. I agree about Ray's voice with the note that it became slightly but noticeably raspier when he found out about his relation to Rustmouth.

name: professorhazard
text: Thanks, Teodor! I thought they had me!

name: echidnaboy
text: Do a tuxedo roll!

name: mjfitzge
text: phillipe's voice (like ray's and every other achewood character's) sounds exactly like mine, since i read the strip out loud.

name: sncether
text: Oh shit! Ray is about to be attacked by a giant finger! Look out, Ray! When did they start animating this comic? oh, wait

name: professorhazard
text: Poor kids love playing this game at the library

name: heccibiggs
text:
You read out loud?

Either you live alone, or everyone hates you.

name: mjfitzge
text: actually both.  the former because of the latter.

name: a-halter
text: Shooting fish in a tuxedo, hilarious.

name: pyromancer
text: I don't think I'd have the heart to shoot a fish that went to the trouble of donning a tuxedo...

name: professorhazard
text: James Pond remains safe in obscurity for another day.

name: irondave
text: Ouch!

name: jamers
text: Someone chubby this man and his pun!

name: professorhazard
text: Thanks, but it's not my pun, jamers. Are you five years too young to know about James Pond ?

name: jamers
text:
Huh. I was around then, but I've never heard of James Pond. I... I think I have a new hero!

The gameplay revolves around finding objects to perform specific tasks, such as keys to rescue captured lobsters, or sponges to bung up the holes in leaking oil tankers. James must also fire bubbles at his enemies to trap them, before popping them to finish them off.

If only James Pond were around for Exxon Valdez...

name: achilleselbow
text: ...you said "bung".

name: professorhazard
text: You must have really enjoyed the Dirty Jobs episode where Mike tried his hand at being a cooper for the day.

name: tekende
text: Dude! When I was a child, I had Super James Pond on the SNES. It was a pretty great game!

name: thorfinn
text: I had it as well, James Pond was awesome.

name: blueloggy
text:
It turns out I'm eight years too old to know about James Pond.

Leisure Suit Larry, on the other hand...

name: professorhazard
text: Never was a fan, but we can have an hour-long conversation about Space Quest, if you like.

name: hellabosque
text: he is Five.

name: bobodante
text: Kids say the darnedest things, right Cos'?

name: stevepants
text: 'i gotta try that man notin's workin' hahaha

name: katal
text: heh!! Tell it like it is, Onstad!

name: hatticus
text: I will now be retroactively reading the Achewood archives with Phillipe's voice as Mitch Hedberg. This may have an adverse affect on his "cute" factor.

name: straw
text: Or a positive one!

name: iidebaser
text: A comment left by iidebaser was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by Thorfinn, FirePowa8, leahpidoptera)

name: tombsgrave
text: Phillipe's talent is as astonishing as it is unnerving.  That last bit is nihilistic as all-get.

name: kharmsengine
text: booyakah

name: odei
text: shah

name: nickgranger
text: i like his little ears

name: tekende
text:
Okay, everyone, there is a Yahoo group set up for the attempt to organize the Great Southwest Acheworld Meetup.

So if you are in the US southwest (Texas, Oklahoma, New Mexico, etc.) and are interested in joining other Achewood fans to turn the mother out, then click here and join.

name: professorhazard
text: I am interested in hearing what sort of activities will be involved in this attempt to turn the mother out.

name: tekende
text:
I don't know. The plans haven't really gotten that far yet. We're still trying to get enough people signed up to the group.

I predict lots of alcohol, though.

name: thorfinn
text: I wish I lived in the SW, this sounds as if it could be quite the shindig.

name: tekende
text: Well, it needn't be limited to just the southwest...anyone willing to travel could attend, I'd imagine.

name: cpnglxynchos
text:
i'm from Colorado and will be going to school in Arizona. it will be a trek but!! i will be there.

BY GOD, I'LL BE THERE.

name: biff
text: I am pretty sure it will involve some form of alcohol consumption.

name: irondave
text: We will be referring frequently to the flowchart.

name: comrade_tom
text: Man 2pm, Phillipe must be headlinin'

name: professorhazard
text: At 2:00 PM, I think most comedy clubs will let basically anybody take the stage.

name: cpnglxynchos
text: are most comedy clubs even open at 2pm?

name: wittyname
text: Maybe Phillipe snuck in and is playing a premade tape.

name: cpnglxynchos
text: that..is the saddest thing.

name: hygraed
text: Philippe is fucking KILLING IT.

name: baryonyx
text:
I heard two drum beats and a cymbal after every panel of this strip.

It didn't make much sense for the shot of the door, I guess. And panel five was sort of a "ba-dum, tshh...?"

name: jawsh
text: philippe's standup is what i think demetri martin's would be if he'd been into the occult as a pre-teen

name: epicurus
text: You saying he wasn't ?

name: shades
text: honestly, Philippe is borderline intolerable for me at this point

name: epicurus
text: I was actually enjoying those until the last two. Can someone explain 'em to me?

name: wittyname
text:
Someone (or two) said above:

It is okay to judge a book by its cover, instead of giving it a good read, when the house you are in is on fire.

I have no idea where the last panel went.

name: bjorntd
text: The otter is comparing women to cockroaches. Smelly, annoying vermin.

name: wittyname
text: Women or the cockroaches?

name: jamers
text: Your avatar suggests you appreciate the comparison...

name: johnnyrocker
text:
It took me about forty reads to get the joke in panel five.

It's actually really funny now.
I still don't really get the pudding one though.

name: i_love_kate
text: He is stating that instead of consuming dessert, English people simply say the word "pudding". The amusement lies in the pragmatic meaning of the first clause. It is implied from the second that in its complete form it would be "Instead of saying dessert," but instead the punchline affirms that the missing verb is indeed, "eating."

name: cpnglxynchos
text: right.

name: dasilodavi
text: I think laughs are harder and more rewarding to obtain than applause.

name: kylemcjuicy
text: a comic once said that if you get laughs your a comedian and if you gets applause you are a motivational speaker. Phillipe appears to be the latter.

name: comrade_tom
text:
wise words, with a name like lazlo's id be expecting the clientele to be clicking their fingers in approval beatnik style.

Beatnik stand up comedy.... the final frontier?

name: achewood
text: This is a phenomenon known as "clapter", a choice that an audience makes to react to jokes with support rather than laughter.

name: carlyle
text: I wanna be the heckler.
